A chest x-ray shows patchy, pulmonary infiltrates bilaterally. A renal biopsy shows linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against the noncollagenous domain of the α-3 subunit in type IV collagen. Type IV collagen is a component of basement membranes, and α-3 subunits are present only in certain tissues (e.g., lungs, kidneys). Therefore, the autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome specifically damage the glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM antibodies) and the alveolar basement membrane, causing nephritic syndrome and alveolar hemorrhage without resulting in features of systemic vasculitis (e.g., fever, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, palpable purpura).

Goodpasture syndrome has a bimodal age distribution: ages 20–30 and 50–70.

B) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis can cause pulmonary-renal syndrome and patchy infiltrates bilaterally. However, the mean age of symptom onset is usually 50 years. Also, patients would have other features such as fever, malaise, weight loss, musculoskeletal pain, a history of bronchial asthma, palpable purpura, and/or clinical features suggestive of multifocal mononeuropathy. Immunohistochemical staining of the renal biopsy specimen would reveal a paucity of immunoglobulins.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy can cause hematuria and it is more common in males 20–40 years of age. Since IgA nephropathy typically develops within 2–3 days of the onset of an infection (e.g., upper respiratory infection), clinical features such as cough, and blood-tinged sputum may also be present. However, the hematuria associated with IgA nephropathy usually resolves after 3–4 days. Also, this patient lacks systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise) to suggest an underlying infectious etiology. Immunohistochemical staining of the renal biopsy specimen would reveal granular deposits of immunoglobulins within the mesangium, instead of linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis can cause pulmonary-renal syndrome and patchy infiltrates bilaterally. However, patients would have other features such as fever, malaise, weight loss, arthralgia, chronic rhinosinusitis, nasal septal perforation/deformity (due to destruction of the nasal septum), and/or cutaneous lesions (e.g., palpable purpura, skin ulcers). Immunohistochemical staining of the renal biopsy specimen would reveal a paucity of immunoglobulins.

E) INCORRECT:

Microscopic polyangiitis can cause pulmonary-renal syndrome and patchy infiltrates bilaterally. However, the mean age of symptom onset is usually 60 years, and patients would have other features such as fever, malaise, weight loss, musculoskeletal pain, and/or palpable purpura. Immunohistochemical staining of the renal biopsy specimen would reveal a paucity of immunoglobulins.
questions.hint: Clinical features of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (e.g., hemoptysis, diffuse crackles, patchy pulmonary infiltrate) and signs of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension, proteinuria, numerous RBC casts, increased serum creatinine) indicate pulmonary-renal syndrome. The presence of linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane (representing anti-GBM antibodies) on kidney biopsy confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old man presents with three days of progressive hemoptysis, exertional dyspnea, and difficulty climbing stairs to the Outpatient Clinic. He has a two-week history of dark-colored urine, mild fatigue, and an occasional metallic taste in his mouth. He denies bleeding from other sites, intravenous drug use, or recent infections, and has no significant medical history. Examination shows fine crackles in both lung bases, conjunctival pallor, mild pedal edema, and normal sinus findings (see lab results and report).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Hemoglobin
95 g/L
130 - 170 g/L


Creatinine
240 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Urine




 Urinalysis
RBC casts: Present
RBC casts: Absent



Chest X-ray: Bilateral patchy opacities
Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome results from IgG autoantibodies targeting the noncollagenous domain of type IV collagen in the basement membranes of renal glomeruli and alveolar capillaries. The patient's hemoptysis, dark-colored urine, elevated creatinine, and red blood cell casts indicate dual pulmonary and renal involvement, characteristic of this condition. Biopsy typically reveals linear immunoglobulin deposits along the glomerular and alveolar basement membranes, indicating antibody-mediated damage. This immune response activates complement, causing capillary injury, alveolar hemorrhage, and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

Key learning point: Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies, leading to pulmonary hemorrhage and glomerulonephritis, presenting with symptoms such as hemoptysis and hematuria.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) commonly affects young women and presents with systemic findings like arthritis and a malar rash, which are absent here. The patient's gender and lack of characteristic SLE symptoms, along with the acute symptom onset, make SLE unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy primarily involves renal manifestations, often following mucosal infections. The presence of progressive hemoptysis and bilateral patchy opacities suggests alveolar hemorrhage, which is not typical of IgA nephropathy, indicating a systemic process affecting both kidneys and lungs.

D) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA) often presents with upper airway symptoms like chronic sinusitis or nasal crusting, which are absent here. Additionally, GPA lung imaging typically shows nodular or cavitary lesions, not bilateral patchy opacities. These factors make GPA less likely.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man presents with a two-week history of cough, low-grade fever, and episodes of blood-tinged sputum. He also notes dark urine and mild flank pain. He has no significant past medical or family history. Physical examination reveals mild pallor. Vital signs are normal. Chest auscultation is unremarkable. Blood cultures are negative (see lab results).


Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
130 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Hemoglobin
115 g/L
130 - 170 g/L



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Granulomatosis with polyangiitis involves the respiratory tract and kidneys, but typically presents with upper respiratory symptoms like sinusitis or nasal crusting, which are absent here. Additionally, cavitary lung lesions or nodular infiltrates are common but not noted. The modest renal impairment is less consistent with the rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis seen in this condition.

B) INCORRECT:

Systemic lupus erythematosus can affect multiple organs, including kidneys and lungs, but often presents with systemic features like a malar rash or arthralgias, which are absent. The acute presentation with blood-tinged sputum and mild flank pain suggests a more rapid process than the typical indolent onset of lupus nephritis.

C) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy primarily affects the kidneys, presenting with hematuria following mucosal infections. It lacks significant pulmonary involvement, such as blood-tinged sputum. The concurrent pulmonary and renal symptoms, along with elevated creatinine and anemia, suggest a systemic process not typical of isolated IgA nephropathy.

D) CORRECT:

Goodpasture's syndrome manifests with hemoptysis and renal involvement due to an antibody-mediated attack on pulmonary and renal basement membranes. The presence of blood-tinged sputum and elevated creatinine indicates concurrent lung and kidney involvement. Autoantibodies target the noncollagenous domain of type IV collagen, causing pulmonary capillaritis and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Anemia from blood loss further supports this diagnosis. Immunofluorescence typically reveals linear deposits along the glomerular basement membrane on renal biopsy, confirming the diagnosis.

Key learning point: Goodpasture's syndrome is characterized by the presence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies leading to glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage, presenting with symptoms such as haemoptysis.

questions.text: A 23-year-old with acute renal failure and hematuria has a biopsy confirming rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Which finding is most characteristic of this process?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Kimmelstiel-Wilson nodules are indicative of diabetic nephropathy, resulting from chronic hyperglycemia and mesangial expansion. They are not associated with the acute renal failure and hematuria seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which involves immunologically mediated glomerular injury.

B) CORRECT:

Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is characterized by crescent formation within Bowman's space. This occurs due to severe glomerular injury, leading to glomerular basement membrane rupture and leakage of plasma proteins like fibrin. The fibrin triggers an inflammatory response, activating parietal epithelial cells and attracting macrophages, resulting in crescent formation. This process rapidly compromises glomerular function, correlating with the acute renal failure observed clinically. Understanding crescent formation is crucial for linking the rapid clinical decline in renal function with the underlying pathology.

Key learning point: Crescent formation within Bowman's space is a hallmark pathological feature of rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).

C) INCORRECT:

Subepithelial spike and dome deposits are associated with membranous nephropathy, characterized by nephrotic syndrome, heavy proteinuria, and edema. This differs from the acute renal failure and hematuria seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, which is marked by crescent formation in Bowman's space.

D) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA immune complexes are typical of IgA nephropathy, presenting with episodic hematuria often post-infection. While some IgA nephropathy cases progress to a crescentic form, the classic lesion in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis involves extensive crescents, not mesangial IgA deposits.

questions.text: You are seeing a 22-year-old man in the emergency department with a 1-week history of dyspnea and hemoptysis. He has no known sick contacts and no personal or family history of serious illness. He does not take any medications. His temperature is 37.0°C, pulse is 82/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 152/90 mm Hg. On examination, there are inspiratory crackles at both lung bases. The remainder of the examination is normal. Laboratory results show hemoglobin 142 g/L (125–170), white blood cell count 10.3 × 109/L (3.5–10.5), and platelet count 205 × 109/L (130–380). Urinalysis reveals proteinuria (2+), 70 RBC/hpf, and 1–2 WBC/hpf. Chest x-ray shows pulmonary infiltrates. Which one of the following laboratory values is most likely to be increased on further evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Increased serum IgA levels can be seen in approximately half of all patients with IgA nephropathy or IgA vasculitis. Both these conditions can cause nephritic syndrome. Features of a pulmonary pathology (e.g., cough, dyspnea, crackles, infiltrates on chest x-ray) may also be present because respiratory infections such as pneumonia can be triggers for IgA nephropathy or IgA vasculitis. This patient, however, does not have fever or leukocytosis, which would suggest an infectious etiology. Also, IgA vasculitis would usually be associated with other features such as palpable purpura (Henoch-Schönlein purpura), abdominal pain, and/or joint pain.

B) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of c-ANCA are commonly seen in granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), which can also cause pulmonary-renal syndrome. However, patients with GPA usually have a history of chronic rhinosinusitis, ocular manifestations (scleritis, episcleritis, uveitis), ulcerating mucocutaneous granulomas, and/or vasculitic purpura. This patient has Goodpasture syndrome, which rarely manifests with increased levels of c-ANCA (< 10% of patients).

C) CORRECT:

Goodpasture syndrome is caused by autoantibodies against the noncollagenous domain of the α3 subunit in type IV collagen. As type IV collagen is a component of basement membranes, and α3 subunits are only present in certain tissues (e.g., lung or kidney tissue), the autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome specifically damage the glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM antibodies) and the alveolar basement membrane. The absence of features of systemic vasculitis (e.g., purpura, livedo reticularis) helps differentiate Goodpasture syndrome from other causes of pulmonary-renal syndrome.

Treatment of Goodpasture syndrome consists of plasmapheresis (to eliminate anti-GBM antibodies) and immunosuppressive therapy (e.g., with cyclophosphamide and corticosteroids).

Key learning point: Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by anti-glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM) antibodies causing both pulmonary hemorrhage and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against the phospholipase A2 receptor (anti-PLA2R) are seen in patients with primary (idiopathic) membranous nephropathy. However, membranous nephropathy typically results in nephrotic syndrome rather than nephritic syndrome.

E) INCORRECT:

Increased levels of p-ANCA are more commonly seen in eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA) or microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), both of which can cause pulmonary-renal syndrome. However, patients with either condition typically have other features of small vessel vasculitis, such as purpura. Patients with EGPA also have a history of bronchial asthma and/or allergic rhinitis. This patient has Goodpasture syndrome, in which only ∼ 25% of patients have increased levels of p-ANCA.
questions.hint: Nephritic syndrome (e.g., microscopic hematuria, hypertension, mild proteinuria) and signs of alveolar hemorrhage (e.g., hemoptysis, dyspnea, pulmonary infiltrates) are consistent with pulmonary-renal syndrome. The absence of features of systemic vasculitis suggests that the underlying cause is Goodpasture syndrome.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old man comes to your clinic with a 2-week history of cough and shortness of breath. He reports several episodes of blood-tinged sputum over the past 4 days and has experienced progressive fatigue for 3 months. His temperature is 37.5°C, pulse is 86/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 150/93 mm Hg. On examination, he has pale conjunctivae and crackles are heard on chest auscultation. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin (Hgb), blood
102 g/L (125–170)


White blood cell (WBC) count, blood
9.2 × 109/L (3.5–10.5)

305 × 109/L (130–380)

136 mmol/L (136–146)

101 mmol/L (98–107)

4.5 mmol/L (3.5–5.1)

25 mmol/L (21–32)


Urea, blood
10.0 mmol/L (2.1–8.0)


Creatinine, blood
203 μmol/L (49–93)


Anti-GBM antibodies
Positive


Antinuclear antibodies
Negative


Blood, urine
2+


Protein, urine
2+


RBC, urine
11–13/hbf


RBC casts, urine
Rare


You start treatment with prednisone and cyclophosphamide. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Rituximab is indicated in the treatment of cANCA-associated vasculitis (granulomatosis with polyangiitis), which may also manifest with pulmonary-renal syndrome. However, individuals with cANCA-associated vasculitis often present with a history of chronic sinusitis, nasal ulcers, and perforation of the nasal septum. Rituximab may also be used to treat patients with Goodpasture syndrome if there is an intolerance to cyclophosphamide.

B) CORRECT:

In patients with Goodpasture syndrome, emergent plasmapheresis is used to eliminate antibodies that are directed at the basement membrane of alveoli and glomeruli (anti-GBM). Immunosuppressive treatment with prednisone and cyclophosphamide is commonly performed in combination with plasmapheresis to reduce new antibody formation. Without proper treatment, Goodpasture syndrome rapidly progresses to end-stage renal disease. However, if therapy is initiated early, full recovery of renal function may be reached in > 50% of cases.

Key learning point: Goodpasture syndrome requires prompt plasmapheresis combined with immunosuppressive therapy to remove anti-GBM antibodies and prevent rapid progression to end-stage renal disease.

C) INCORRECT:

Hemodialysis is performed when the kidney transiently or persistently loses its function to remove toxins, metabolites, and water from the body. Because Goodpasture syndrome often leads to end-stage renal disease, this patient will likely require hemodialysis in the future. However, it is not currently indicated.

D) INCORRECT:

Immune globulins are used for the treatment of a variety of conditions, including certain autoimmune diseases, immunodeficiencies, and infections. Although Goodpasture syndrome is an autoimmune disease that involves the lungs and kidneys, immune globulins are not part of the routine treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Enalapril is an ACE inhibitor that is commonly used in the treatment of hypertension. Renal involvement related to Goodpasture syndrome is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's hypertension. ACE inhibitors have a nephroprotective effect, making them especially useful for patients with renal disease. Although treatment with enalapril could become necessary at some point, it is not the best next step in management at this time.
questions.hint: Fatigue, cough with hemoptysis, elevated creatinine and urea nitrogen, and nephritic sediment (hematuria, red blood cell casts, proteinuria) on urinalysis indicate pulmonary-renal syndrome. Evidence of anti-glomerular basement membrane antibodies (anti-GBM) is diagnostic for Goodpasture syndrome.

AIN is often drug-induced (e.g., from cephalosporins) and manifests with fever, rash, pyuria, and costovertebral angle tenderness, which this patient does not have.

C) INCORRECT:

This finding is typically seen in patients with acute tubular necrosis (ATN), a condition commonly preceded by ischemic injury (e.g., renal hypoperfusion due to hypovolemia or shock) or nephrotoxic injury (e.g., exposure to radiocontrast agents). This patient has no history of these risk factors.

D) CORRECT:

RBC casts are often seen in patients with nephritic syndrome, a condition caused by glomerular inflammation (e.g., from post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis or rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). This inflammatory process releases cytokines and results in damaged, porous glomerular capillaries. RBCs leak through these spaces, accumulate, and form casts in the renal tubules. RBC casts appear on urinalysis as a cluster of biconcave, disc-shaped RBCs enclosed in a tubular mucoprotein cast.

Key learning point: Red blood cell casts on urinalysis are a hallmark of nephritic syndrome, indicating glomerular inflammation and bleeding into the renal tubules.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of urine sediment (phase-contrast microscopy)

A tubular cast (blue overlay) is visible in the center of the image. The cast is composed of numerous RBCs, identifiable by their characteristic biconvex shape (examples outlined in yellow), in a matrix of fibrin and plasma proteins. Several epithelial cells surrounding the RBC cast are also visible.

RBC casts in urinary sediment are typically seen in glomerulonephritis.

E) INCORRECT:

Urinary rhomboid crystals seen on urinalysis are pathognomonic for uric acid crystals, which are not associated with nephritic syndrome. This finding is typically seen in patients with hyperuricemia, which can cause uric acid nephrolithiasis and urate nephropathy. Nephrolithiasis can cause hematuria but also commonly results in severe, unilateral, colicky flank pain. Chronic urate nephropathy can manifest with hypertension, edema, and oliguria, as seen in this patient. However, it does not cause hematuria and is usually preceded by gout.
questions.hint: This man has edema, hematuria, azotemia, hypertension, and oliguria, which are all features of nephritic syndrome.

Therefore, the autoantibodies in Goodpasture syndrome specifically damage the glomerular basement membrane (anti-GBM antibodies) and the alveolar basement membrane, causing nephritic syndrome and alveolar hemorrhage without resulting in features of systemic vasculitis (e.g., fever, malaise, myalgia, arthralgia, palpable purpura).

Goodpasture syndrome has a bimodal age distribution: ages 20–30 and 50–70.

Key learning point: Goodpasture syndrome is characterized by anti-GBM antibodies targeting type IV collagen, causing rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis and pulmonary hemorrhage with linear IgG deposition along the glomerular basement membrane.

D) INCORRECT:

Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis can cause pulmonary-renal syndrome and patchy infiltrates bilaterally. However, the mean age of symptom onset is usually 50 years. Also, patients would have other features such as fever, malaise, weight loss, musculoskeletal pain, a history of bronchial asthma, palpable purpura, and/or clinical features suggestive of multifocal mononeuropathy. Immunohistochemical staining of the renal biopsy specimen would reveal a paucity of immunoglobulins.

E) INCORRECT:

IgA nephropathy can cause hematuria and it is more common in males 20–40 years of age. Since IgA nephropathy typically develops within 2–3 days of the onset of an infection (e.g., upper respiratory infection), clinical features such as cough, and blood-tinged sputum may also be present. However, the hematuria associated with IgA nephropathy usually resolves after 3–4 days. Also, this patient lacks systemic symptoms (e.g., fever, malaise) to suggest an underlying infectious etiology. Immunohistochemical staining of the renal biopsy specimen would reveal granular deposits of immunoglobulins within the mesangium, instead of linear deposits of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane.
questions.hint: Clinical features of diffuse alveolar hemorrhage (e.g., hemoptysis, diffuse crackles, patchy pulmonary infiltrate) and signs of nephritic syndrome (e.g., hypertension, proteinuria, numerous RBC casts, increased serum creatinine) indicate pulmonary-renal syndrome. The presence of linear deposition of IgG along the glomerular basement membrane (representing anti-GBM antibodies) on kidney biopsy confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of progressive dyspnea, fatigue, and dark urine. Her medical history includes chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal crusting for 6 months. Physical examination shows hypertension, bilateral lower extremity edema, and saddle nose deformity. Urinalysis shows proteinuria, hematuria, and red blood cell casts. Serum creatinine has increased from 1.2 mg/dL to 3.8 mg/dL over 2 weeks. Chest imaging shows bilateral cavitary pulmonary nodules. Based on the clinical presentation, which laboratory test would be most appropriate to confirm the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Elevated serum IgA levels are associated with IgA nephropathy, which is the most common form of primary glomerulonephritis worldwide. However, IgA nephropathy typically presents with episodic gross hematuria following upper respiratory infections and does not cause the chronic rhinosinusitis and pulmonary lesions seen in this patient. In addition, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, as suggested in this patient by the rate of renal function deterioration, is uncommon in IgA nephropathy.

B) INCORRECT:

Anti-dsDNA antibodies are specific for systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and associated lupus nephritis. While SLE can cause glomerulonephritis, the chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal crusting and cavitary pulmonary lesions are not typical manifestations of SLE. Additionally, this patient’s age and presentation pattern are more consistent with antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated vasculitis than systemic lupus erythematosus.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- The constellation of chronic rhinosinusitis with nasal crusting, saddle nose deformity, rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis, and cavitary pulmonary lesions strongly suggests granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). This antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (ANCA)-associated vasculitis typically affects the upper respiratory tract, lungs, and kidneys. Antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCAs) are positive in over 90% of patients with generalized GPA, consisting of PR3-ANCA in approximately 75% of patients and MPO-ANCA in approximately 20% of patients. The rapidly progressive nature of the renal dysfunction and the characteristic triad of upper airways, lungs, and kidneys make GPA the most likely diagnosis requiring confirmation with ANCA testing.

D) INCORRECT:

Anti-GBM antibodies are associated with Goodpasture disease, which can present with pulmonary-renal syndrome. However, this condition typically lacks the chronic upper respiratory tract involvement and cavitary lung lesions characteristic of granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA). Anti-GBM disease also tends to have a more acute onset without the prolonged history of rhinosinusitis present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Antistreptococcal antibodies are elevated in poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, which typically follows a streptococcal infection by 1–6 weeks. However, this condition does not typically cause significant pulmonary involvement or cavitary lesions. The patient's age, chronic rhinosinusitis, and saddle nose deformity also make another type of glomerulonephritis more likely in this case.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department with a 10-day history of cola-colored urine and facial swelling. He reports decreased urine output over the past 3 days. Vital signs are BP, 165/95; P, 88. Oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Physical examination reveals an alert patient with mild pitting edema of the face and ankles, and fine bilateral crackles at the lung bases. Laboratory results show sodium 138 mEq/L, potassium 5.1 mEq/L, chloride 101 mEq/L, CO2 18 mEq/L, glucose 92 mg/dL, serum creatinine 4.2 mg/dL (baseline 1.1 mg/dL two months ago), and BUN 68 mg/dL. Urinalysis reveals 3+ blood, 2+ protein, and numerous red blood cell casts. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While intravenous methylprednisolone is part of the treatment regimen for rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN), initiating immunosuppressive therapy prior to definitive diagnosis is usually not appropriate. The specific underlying cause should be determined before starting treatment. Empiric immunosuppressive therapy may be considered with specialist consultation if kidney biopsy or interpretation are significantly delayed.

B) INCORRECT:

Intravenous immunoglobulin is not a standard treatment for rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. The typical immunosuppressive regimen includes glucocorticoids plus cyclophosphamide or rituximab, depending on the underlying cause as determined by renal biopsy.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient may eventually require renal replacement therapy, but inserting a dialysis catheter is premature, as he does not currently meet urgent dialysis indications.

D) INCORRECT:

Angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitors are appropriate for long-term management of proteinuria and hypertension in glomerular disease, but starting this medication does not address the urgent need for definitive diagnosis. Additionally, initiation of ACE inhibitors may not be advisable in patients with rapidly worsening renal functions.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with clinical features suggesting rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): a rapid rise in creatinine with nephritic sediment and oliguria developing over days to weeks. RPGN can progress to end-stage renal disease within 3 months without early treatment. Urgent nephrology consultation is essential for prompt renal biopsy, definitive diagnosis, and initiation of appropriate immunosuppressive therapy.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his mother because he has had puffiness around his eyes for the past three days and dark, 'cola-colored' urine. Two weeks ago, he was treated for a sore throat. His blood pressure is 135/85 mm Hg. Physical examination shows periorbital and pedal edema. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on microscopic examination of this patient's urine sediment?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Waxy casts are broad, acellular casts with sharp borders that are thought to represent the final stage of cast degeneration. Their presence suggests urinary stasis and is a feature of advanced, chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease. This patient's presentation is acute, which makes chronic kidney disease an unlikely diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Muddy brown granular casts are pathognomonic for acute tubular necrosis, which involves damage and sloughing of renal tubular epithelial cells, often from an ischemic or nephrotoxic insult. Although severe glomerulonephritis can cause acute kidney injury, the primary pathology is glomerular inflammation, not tubular necrosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Fatty casts are a feature of nephrotic syndrome, which is characterized by heavy proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. Although this patient has edema, a feature shared with nephrotic syndrome, the prominent findings of 'cola-colored' urine (hematuria) and hypertension are more indicative of a nephritic process. Fatty casts, which appear as 'Maltese crosses' under polarized light, would not be the primary finding.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis, a form of acute nephritic syndrome. The pathophysiology involves glomerular inflammation and damage due to immune complex deposition following a Group A Streptococcus infection. This damage to the glomerular basement membrane allows erythrocytes to leak into the Bowman space and renal tubules. Within the tubules, these erythrocytes become trapped in a protein matrix (Tamm-Horsfall mucoprotein), forming red blood cell casts. The presence of RBC casts is pathognomonic for glomerular bleeding and is the hallmark finding of glomerulonephritis. The 'cola-colored' urine is a result of gross hematuria.

E) INCORRECT:

White blood cell casts indicate inflammation within the renal tubules and interstitium, not the glomeruli. They are characteristic of conditions such as acute pyelonephritis or acute interstitial nephritis. Although this patient had a recent infection, he does not have the typical signs of pyelonephritis, such as fever, flank pain, or dysuria, which makes this finding unlikely.
questions.hint: This patient's recent history of a sore throat, followed by the classic triad of hematuria, edema, and hypertension, suggests an acute nephritic syndrome.

questions.text:
A 13-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of swelling around his eyes for the past 2 days. His mother also notes that his urine became gradually darker during this time. Three weeks ago, he was treated for bacterial tonsillitis. His temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 79/min, and blood pressure is 158/87 mm Hg. Examination shows periorbital swelling. Laboratory studies show:


Serum



Urea nitrogen
9 mg/dL


Creatinine
1.7 mg/dL


Urine



Protein
2+


RBC
12/hpf


RBC casts
numerous


A renal biopsy would most likely show which of the following findings?

choices.text: "Spike-and-dome" appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy
Splitting and alternating thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy
Effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy
Granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 on immunofluorescence
Glomerular crescent moon formation on light microscopy

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A “spike-and-dome” appearance of subepithelial deposits on electron microscopy is a typical finding of membranous nephropathy (MN). This condition usually manifests with nephrotic syndrome, as opposed to the nephritic syndrome seen in this patient. MN rarely manifests in childhood; however, when children are affected, the most common associations include hepatitis B infection and autoimmune or thyroid disease, none of which is present in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Splitting and alternating thickening and thinning of the glomerular basement membrane on light microscopy may be seen in both Alport syndrome and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). These conditions typically manifest with nephritic syndrome, which is seen in this patient. However, other characteristic features of Alport syndrome include visual disturbances and sensorineural hearing loss, neither of which this patient has. MPGN can either be secondary to infection (e.g., hepatitis C) or autoimmune disease, of which there is no evidence in this patient, or idiopathic. This patient's recent history of bacterial tonsillitis suggests a different diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Mesangial IgA-based immune complex deposits on immunofluorescence are a typical finding of IgA nephropathy. This type of glomerulonephritis may manifest with nephritic syndrome, which is seen in this patient. However, IgA nephropathy most commonly occurs during or immediately following (2–5 days) an upper respiratory/gastrointestinal tract infection and not 2–4 weeks after. Also, IgA nephropathy is not typically associated with bacterial tonsillitis.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney tissue (PAS stain)

A glomerulus surrounded by numerous tubules is visible in the center of each image. There is a proliferation of mesangial cells (examples marked by yellow circles) with extracellular matrix deposition within the glomeruli. In IgA nephropathy, these changes can range from focal segmental (examples indicated by black arrows) to diffuse (examples indicated by yellow arrow-heads).

This is the characteristic histopathologic appearance of IgA nephropathy.

Blue outlines: Glomerular capillaries

D) INCORRECT:

Effacement of podocyte foot processes on electron microscopy is a typical finding of minimal change disease (MCD). MCD is most commonly seen in children. However, it manifests with nephrotic syndrome, as opposed to the nephritic syndrome seen in this patient. MCD is mainly idiopathic but may be triggered by recent infections or develop secondary to lymphoma.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of kidney tissue

The effacement of the podocytes foot processes is visible (examples indicated by green outline) as well as swelling of podocyte bodies (example indicated by red overlay).

This finding, together with unremarkable light microscopy, is typical of minimal change disease.

E) CORRECT:

Typical renal biopsy findings of PSGN include granular deposits of IgG, IgM, and C3 along the glomerular basement membrane and mesangium on immunofluorescence (“lumpy-bumpy” or “starry sky” appearance), enlarged and hypercellular glomeruli on light microscopy, and subepithelial immune complex deposits (“humps”) on electron microscopy. In response to infection with nephritogenic strains of group A streptococci (e.g., bacterial tonsillitis), immune complexes containing the streptococcal antigen deposit in the subendothelial and subepithelial space. These immune complexes trigger an immune response (via complement activation) that destroys glomeruli. The subendothelial deposits are rapidly cleared by circulating immune cells and may not be present on renal biopsy unless performed in the early stages of PSGN.
Image Description:

Fluorescence microscopy (immunofluorescence staining for C3; high magnification)

Granular deposits of C3 are visible, resulting in a starry sky pattern.

F) INCORRECT:

Glomerular crescent moon formation on light microscopy is seen in rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN). RPGN is characterized by the rapid destruction of renal glomeruli manifesting as nephritic syndrome, which is seen here. Although poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) can progress to RPGN, normal blood urea nitrogen, relatively mild creatinine elevation, and no changes in urinary output after 2 days of PSGN make RPGN unlikely in this patient.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of kidney biopsy tissue (H&E stain; high magnification)

A hypercellular, crescent-shaped zone with an inflammatory infiltrate (yellow overlay) is visible within the glomerulus.

Glomerular crescent formation is a characteristic histological finding in RPGN.
questions.hint: This patient presents with signs and symptoms of nephritic syndrome (periorbital edema, gross hematuria with RBC casts, mild proteinuria, elevated creatinine, and hypertension) 3 weeks after an episode of bacterial tonsillitis. This presentation should raise suspicion for poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).
